snippet: The European Court of Justice, hearing the case of a Romanian migrant in Germany, ruled that member nations may withhold benefits to immigrants from other, usually poorer, member nations.
abstract: European Court of Justice rules that a Romanian woman who immigrated to Germany is not entitled to unemployment benefits because she had not tried to find a job; ruling has widespread implications for number of countries, like Britain and Germany, that have complained of so-called 'welfare tourism' and that have faced strong opposition at home over immigration policies.

byline.contributor: Stephen Castle contributed reporting from London, and James Kanter from Brussels.

lead_paragraph: The European Court of Justice, hearing the case of a Romanian migrant in Germany, ruled that member nations may withhold benefits to immigrants from other, usually poorer, member nations.

headline.main: Court Lets E.U. Nations Curb Immigrant Welfare
headline.print_headline: Court Lets E.U. Nations Curb Immigrant Welfare
